member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyFeatures.spatial_grid_1
member.summary: The Output Spatial Grid 1, 2, and 3 parameters apply only to file geodatabases and certain enterprise geodatabase feature classes. If you are unfamiliar with setting grid sizes, leave these options as 0,0,0 and ArcGIS will compute optimal sizes for you. For more information about this parameter, refer to the Add Spatial Index tool documentation. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyFeatures.spatial_grid_2
member.summary: Cell size of the second spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want one grid. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Output Spatial Grid 1. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyFeatures.spatial_grid_3
member.summary:
Cell size of the third spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want two grids. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Output Spatial Grid 2.
(In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeFeatureLayer
member.summary: Creates a feature layer from an input feature class or layer file. The layer that is created by the tool is temporary and will not persist after the session ends unless the layer is saved to disk or the map document is saved.

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The input feature class or layer from which to make the new layer. Complex feature classes, such as annotation and dimensions, are not valid inputs to this tool. (In, Required)
The name of the feature layer to be created. The newly created layer can be used as input to any geoprocessing tool that accepts a feature layer as input. (Out, Required)

member.summary: The input feature class or layer from which to make the new layer. Complex feature classes, such as annotation and dimensions, are not valid inputs to this tool. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeFeatureLayer.where_clause
member.summary: An SQL expression used to select a subset of features. For more information on SQL syntax see the help topic SQL reference for query expressions used in ArcGIS. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeFeatureLayer.workspace
member.summary: The input workspace used to validate the field names. If the input is a geodatabase table and the output workspace is a dBASE table, the field names may be truncated, since dBASE fields can only have names of ten characters or less. The new names may be reviewed and altered using the field information control. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeFeatureLayer.field_info
member.summary: Can be used to review and alter the field names and hide a subset of fields in the output layer. A split policy can be specified. See the usages for more information. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The type of the data on disk to be copied. member.summary: The enterprise, file, or personal geodatabase, or the folder in which the output feature class will be created. This workspace must already exist. (In, Required)

member.summary: The geometry type of the feature class. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The feature class used as a template to define the attribute schema of the feature class. (In, Optional)

member.summary: Determines if the feature class contains linear measurement values (m-values). (In, Optional)

member.summary: Determines if the feature class contains elevation values (z-values). (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateFeatureclass.spatial_reference
member.summary: The spatial reference of the output feature dataset. You can specify the spatial reference in the following ways: Enter the path to a .prj file, such as C:/workspace/watershed.prj. Reference a feature class or feature dataset whose spatial reference you want to apply, such as C:/workspace/myproject.gdb/landuse/grassland.Define a spatial reference object prior to using this tool, such as sr = arcpy.SpatialReference("C:/data/Africa/Carthage.prj"), which you then use as the spatial reference parameter. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateFeatureclass.config_keyword
member.summary: The configuration keyword applies to enterprise data only. It determines the storage parameters of the database table. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateFeatureclass.spatial_grid_1
member.summary: The Spatial Grid 1, 2, and 3 parameters are used to compute a spatial index and only apply to file geodatabases and certain workgroup and enterprise geodatabase feature classes. If you are unfamiliar with setting grid sizes, leave these options as 0,0,0 and ArcGIS will compute optimal sizes for you. Since no features are written by this tool, the spatial index will be in an unbuilt state. The index will be built when features are written to the feature class such as by the Append tool or editing operations. For more information about this parameter, refer to the Add Spatial Index tool documentation. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateFeatureclass.spatial_grid_2
member.summary: Cell size of the second spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want one grid. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Spatial Grid 1. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateFeatureclass.spatial_grid_3
member.summary:
Cell size of the third spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want two grids. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Spatial Grid 2.
(In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateRelationshipClass
member.summary: This tool creates a relationship class to store an association between fields or features in the origin table and the destination table.

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The table or feature class that is associated to the destination table. (In, Required)
The table that is associated to the origin table. (In, Required)
The relationship class that is created. (Out, Required)
The type of relationship to create between the origin and destination tables. (In, Required)
A name to uniquely identify the relationship when navigating from the origin table to the destination table. (In, Required)
A name to uniquely identify the relationship when navigating from the destination table to the origin table. (In, Required)

The direction in which messages are passed between the origin and destination tables. For example, in a relationship between poles and transformers, when the pole is deleted, it sends a message to its related transformer objects informing them it was deleted. (In, Required)
Determines how many relationships exist between rows or features in the origin and rows or features in the destination table. (In, Required)

param.name: attributed
param.summary: Specifies if the relationship will have attributes. (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.TableToRelationshipClass
member.summary: Creates an attributed relationship class from the origin, destination, and relationship tables.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.TableToRelationshipClass.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The table or feature class that will be associated to the destination table. (In, Required)
The table or feature class that will be associated to the origin table. (In, Required)
The relationship class that will be created. (Out, Required)
The type of association to create between the origin and destination tables. (In, Required)
A label describing the relationship as it is traversed from the origin table/feature class to the destination table/feature class. (In, Required)
A label describing the relationship as it is traversed from the destination table/feature class to the origin table/feature class. (In, Required)

The direction messages will be propagated between the objects in the relationship. For example, in a relationship between poles and transformers, when the pole is deleted, it sends a message to its related transformer objects informing them it was deleted. (In, Required)
The cardinality of the relationship between the origin and destination. (In, Required)
The table containing attributes that will be added to the relationship class. (In, Required)
The fields containing attribute values that will be added to the relationship class. (In, Required)

The name of the Foreign Key field in the relationship table that refers to the Primary Key field in the origin table/feature class. (In, Required)

The field in the relationship table that refers to the Primary Key field in the destination table. (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Eliminate
member.summary: Eliminates polygons by merging them with neighboring polygons that have the largest area or the longest shared border. Eliminate is often used to remove small sliver polygons that are the result of overlay operations, such as Intersect or Union.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Eliminate.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology
member.summary: Adds a feature class to a topology.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The topology to which the feature class will participate. (In, Required)
The feature class to add to the topology. The feature class must be in the same feature dataset as the topology. (In, Required)

The relative degree of positional accuracy associated with vertices of features in the feature class versus those in other feature classes participating in the topology. The feature class with the highest accuracy should get a higher rank (lower number, for example, 1) than a feature class which is known to be less accurate. (In, Required)

Feature classes that are z-aware have elevation values embedded in their geometry for each vertex. By setting a z rank, you can influence how vertices with accurate z-values are snapped or clustered with vertices that contain less accurate z measurements. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology.in_topology
member.summary: The topology to which the feature class will participate. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology.in_featureclass
member.summary: The feature class to add to the topology. The feature class must be in the same feature dataset as the topology. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology.xy_rank
member.summary: The relative degree of positional accuracy associated with vertices of features in the feature class versus those in other feature classes participating in the topology. The feature class with the highest accuracy should get a higher rank (lower number, for example, 1) than a feature class which is known to be less accurate. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddFeatureClassToTopology.z_rank
member.summary: Feature classes that are z-aware have elevation values embedded in their geometry for each vertex. By setting a z rank, you can influence how vertices with accurate z-values are snapped or clustered with vertices that contain less accurate z measurements. (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable
member.summary: This tool applies an SQL query to a database, and the results are represented in a layer or table view. The query can be used to join several tables or return a subset of fields or rows from the original data in the database.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The name of the table or tables to be used in the query. If several tables are listed, the where_clause parameter can be used to define how they are to be joined. (In, Required)
The name of the layer or table view that will be created by the tool. (Out, Required)

Layers and table views in ArcGIS require an ObjectID field. An ObjectID field is an integer field used to uniquely identify rows in the data being used. In this tool, this parameter is used to indicate how an ObjectID field will be generated (if at all) for the query. The default is Use key fields (USE_KEY_FIELDS in Python). (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.in_table
member.summary: The name of the table or tables to be used in the query. If several tables are listed, the where_clause parameter can be used to define how they are to be joined. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.out_table
member.summary: The name of the layer or table view that will be created by the tool. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.in_key_field_option
member.summary: Layers and table views in ArcGIS require an ObjectID field. An ObjectID field is an integer field used to uniquely identify rows in the data being used. In this tool, this parameter is used to indicate how an ObjectID field will be generated (if at all) for the query. The default is Use key fields (USE_KEY_FIELDS in Python). (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.in_key_field
member.summary: Specifies a field or combination of fields that can be used to uniquely identify a row in the query. This parameter is used only when USE_KEY_FIELDS is set. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.in_field
member.summary: The fields to include in the layer or table view. If an alias is set for a field, this is the name that appears. If no fields are specified, all fields from all tables are included. If a Shape field is added to the field list, the result is a layer; otherwise it is a table view. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.MakeQueryTable.where_clause

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate
member.summary: Turn a raster dataset around a pivot point.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: Select the raster dataset to rotate. (In, Required)

Specify a name, location, and format for the dataset you are creating. When storing a raster dataset in a geodatabase, do not add a file extension to the name of the raster dataset. When storing your raster dataset to a JPEG file, a JPEG 2000 file, a TIFF file, or a geodatabase, you can specify a compression type and compression quality. (Out, Required)

Specify a value between 0 and 360 degrees to rotate the raster by that amount in the clockwise direction. To rotate the raster in the counterclockwise direction, specify the angle as a negative value. The angle can be specified as an integer or a floating-point value. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.in_raster
member.summary: Select the raster dataset to rotate. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.out_raster
member.summary: Specify a name, location, and format for the dataset you are creating. When storing a raster dataset in a geodatabase, do not add a file extension to the name of the raster dataset. When storing your raster dataset to a JPEG file, a JPEG 2000 file, a TIFF file, or a geodatabase, you can specify a compression type and compression quality. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.angle
member.summary: Specify a value between 0 and 360 degrees to rotate the raster by that amount in the clockwise direction. To rotate the raster in the counterclockwise direction, specify the angle as a negative value. The angle can be specified as an integer or a floating-point value. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.pivot_point
member.summary: Select a point to rotate the raster around. If left blank, the lower left corner of the input raster dataset will serve as the pivot. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.resampling_type
member.summary: The resampling algorithm to be used. The default is NEAREST. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Rotate.clipping_extent
member.summary: Specify the processing extent of the raster dataset. The source data will be clipped to the specified extent before rotation. (In, Optional)

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

The name of the field that will be added to the input table. (In, Required)
The field type of the new field. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.in_table
member.summary: The input table to which the specified field will be added. The field will be added to the existing input table and will not create a new output table. (In, Required)

member.summary: The name of the field that will be added to the input table. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_precision
member.summary: The number of digits that can be stored in the field. All digits are counted no matter what side of the decimal they are on. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_scale
member.summary: The number of decimal places stored in a field. This parameter is only used in float and double data field types. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_length
member.summary: The length of the field being added. This sets the maximum number of allowable characters for each record of the field. This option is only applicable on fields of type text. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_alias
member.summary: The alternate name given to the field name. This name is used to give more descriptive names to cryptic field names. The field alias parameter only applies to geodatabases. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_is_nullable
member.summary: Specifies whether the field can contain null values. Null values are different from zero or empty fields and are only supported for fields in a geodatabase. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_is_required
member.summary: Specifies whether the field being created is a required field for the table and is only supported for fields in a geodatabase. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddField.field_domain
member.summary: Used to constrain the values allowed in any particular attribute for a table, feature class, or subtype in a geodatabase. You must specify the name of an existing domain for it to be applied to the field. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate
member.summary: Analyzes the coordinate locations of feature vertices among features in one or more feature classes. Those that fall within a specified distance of one another are assumed to represent the same location and are assigned a common coordinate value (in other words, they are colocated). The tool also adds vertices where feature vertices are within the x,y tolerance of an edge and where line segments intersect.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The feature classes to be integrated. When the distance between features is small in comparison to the tolerance, the vertices or points will be clustered (moved to be coincident). The feature class or layer with the lower rank will snap to the feature from the feature class or layer with the higher rank (with 1 being a higher rank than 2). Features in the feature class with a rank of 1 may move when a large x,y tolerance is used. For more information, see Priority ranks and geoprocessing tools. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.in_features
member.summary: The feature classes to be integrated. When the distance between features is small in comparison to the tolerance, the vertices or points will be clustered (moved to be coincident). The feature class or layer with the lower rank will snap to the feature from the feature class or layer with the higher rank (with 1 being a higher rank than 2). Features in the feature class with a rank of 1 may move when a large x,y tolerance is used. For more information, see Priority ranks and geoprocessing tools. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.cluster_tolerance
member.summary: The distance that determines the range in which feature vertices are made coincident. To minimize undesired movement of vertices, the x,y tolerance should be fairly small. If no value is specified, the xy tolerance from the first dataset in the list of inputs will be used. It is recommended that you leave this parameter unset and allow the x,y tolerance to default to the data's spatial reference x,y tolerance. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.out_features
member.summary: Output Features (out, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.ToolboxDirectory
member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool's toolbox.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.ToolName
member.summary: The name of this tool.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.Alias
member.summary: The alias for this tool's toolbox.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Integrate.ParameterInfo
member.summary: The parameters used by this tool. For internal use only.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare
member.summary: Compares two feature classes or layers and returns the comparison results.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The Input Base Features are compared with the Input Test Features. Input Base Features refers to data that you have declared valid. This base data has the correct geometry definitions, field definitions, and spatial reference. (In, Required)
The Input Test Features are compared against the Input Base Features. Input Test Features refers to data that you have made changes to by editing or compiling new features. (In, Required)

The field or fields used to sort records in the Input Base Features and the Input Test Features. The records are sorted in ascending order. Sorting by a common field in both the Input Base Features and the Input Test Features ensures that you are comparing the same row from each input dataset. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.in_base_features
member.summary: The Input Base Features are compared with the Input Test Features. Input Base Features refers to data that you have declared valid. This base data has the correct geometry definitions, field definitions, and spatial reference. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.in_test_features
member.summary: The Input Test Features are compared against the Input Base Features. Input Test Features refers to data that you have made changes to by editing or compiling new features. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.sort_field
member.summary: The field or fields used to sort records in the Input Base Features and the Input Test Features. The records are sorted in ascending order. Sorting by a common field in both the Input Base Features and the Input Test Features ensures that you are comparing the same row from each input dataset. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.compare_type
member.summary: The comparison type. The default is All, which will compare all properties of the features being compared. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.ignore_options
member.summary: These properties will not be compared. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.xy_tolerance
member.summary: The distance that determines the range in which features are considered equal. To minimize error, the value you choose for the compare tolerance should be as small as possible. By default, the compare tolerance is the XY tolerance of the input base features. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.m_tolerance
member.summary: The measure tolerance is the minimum distance between measures before they are considered equal. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.z_tolerance
member.summary: The Z Tolerance is the minimum distance between z coordinates before they are considered equal. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.attribute_tolerances
member.summary: The numeric value that determines the range in which attribute values are considered equal. This only applies to numeric field types. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.omit_field
member.summary: The field or fields that will be omitted during comparison. The field definitions and the tabular values for these fields will be ignored. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.continue_compare
member.summary: Indicates whether to compare all properties after encountering the first mismatch. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.FeatureCompare.out_compare_file
member.summary: This file will contain all similarities and differences between the in_base_features and the in_test_features. This file is a comma-delimited text file that can be viewed and used as a table in ArcGIS. (Out, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation
member.summary: Creates a transformation method for converting data between two geographic coordinate systems or datums. The output of this tool can be used as a transformation method for any tool with a parameter that requires a geographic transformation.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation.#ctor(System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: Name of the custom transformation method. (In, Required)
The starting geographic coordinate system. (In, Required)
The final geographic coordinate system. (Out, Required)

Set the METHOD and PARAMETER values wrapped in a string for custom transformation GEOGTRAN. Set the name of the method from the available methods of Geocentric_Translation, Molodensky, Molodensky_Abridged, Position_Vector, Coordinate_Frame, Molodensky_Badekas, NADCON, HARN, NTV2, Longitude_Rotation, Unit_Change, and Geographic_2D_Offset. Each method has its own sets of parametersâ€”you can edit the values of the parameters by entering text next to the name of the parameter within the whole string representation of the custom geographic transformation. See examples in the Python sample below. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation.geot_name
member.summary: Name of the custom transformation method. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation.in_coor_system
member.summary: The starting geographic coordinate system. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation.out_coor_system
member.summary: The final geographic coordinate system. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateCustomGeoTransformation.custom_geot
member.summary: Set the METHOD and PARAMETER values wrapped in a string for custom transformation GEOGTRAN. Set the name of the method from the available methods of Geocentric_Translation, Molodensky, Molodensky_Abridged, Position_Vector, Coordinate_Frame, Molodensky_Badekas, NADCON, HARN, NTV2, Longitude_Rotation, Unit_Change, and Geographic_2D_Offset. Each method has its own sets of parametersâ€”you can edit the values of the parameters by entering text next to the name of the parameter within the whole string representation of the custom geographic transformation. See examples in the Python sample below. (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica
member.summary: Creates a replica to a geodatabase from a specified list of feature classes, layers, datasets, and/or tables in an enterprise geodatabase.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The data to be replicated. This list consists of layers and tables referencing versioned, editable data from an enterprise geodatabase. (In, Required)
The kind of replica to create. (In, Required)

The local geodatabase or geodata service that will host the child replica. Geodata services are used to represent remote geodatabases. The geodatabase can be an enterprise, file, or personal geodatabase. For two-way replicas the child geodatabase must be an enterprise geodatabase. For one-way and check-out replicas the geodatabase can be personal, file, or enterprise geodatabase. Personal or file geodatabases must already exist before running this tool. (In, Required)
The name that identifies the replica. (In, Required)

param.name: archiving
param.summary: Specifies whether to use the archive class to track changes instead of using the versioning delta tables. This is only available for one-way replicas. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.in_data
member.summary: The data to be replicated. This list consists of layers and tables referencing versioned, editable data from an enterprise geodatabase. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.in_type
member.summary: The kind of replica to create. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.out_geodatabase
member.summary: The local geodatabase or geodata service that will host the child replica. Geodata services are used to represent remote geodatabases. The geodatabase can be an enterprise, file, or personal geodatabase. For two-way replicas the child geodatabase must be an enterprise geodatabase. For one-way and check-out replicas the geodatabase can be personal, file, or enterprise geodatabase. Personal or file geodatabases must already exist before running this tool. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.out_name
member.summary: The name that identifies the replica. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.access_type
member.summary: The type of access you want: (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.initial_data_sender
member.summary: Used by replication to determine which replica can send changes when in disconnected mode. If you are working in a connected mode, this parameter is inconsequential. This ensures that the relative replica doesn't send updates until the changes are first received from the initial data sender. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.expand_feature_classes_and_tables
member.summary: Specifies whether you will include expanded feature classes and tables, such as those found in geometric networks, topologies, or relationship classes. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.reuse_schema
member.summary: Indicates whether to reuse a geodatabase that contains the schema of the data you want to replicate. This reduces the amount of time required to replicate the data. This option is only available for check-out replicas. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.get_related_data
member.summary: Specifies whether to replicate rows related to rows already in the replica. For example, consider a feature (f1) inside the replication filter and a related feature (f2) from another class outside the filter. Feature f2 is included in the replica if you choose to get related data. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.geometry_features
member.summary: The features used to define the area to replicate. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.archiving
member.summary: Specifies whether to use the archive class to track changes instead of using the versioning delta tables. This is only available for one-way replicas. (In, Required)

member.summary: Output Child Workspace (out, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateReplica.output_replica_name
member.summary: Output Replica Name (out, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges
member.summary: Synchronizes updates between two replica geodatabases in a direction specified by the user.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The geodatabase hosting the replica to synchronize. The geodatabase may be local or remote. (In, Required)
A valid replica with a parent contained within one input geodatabase and a child in the other input geodatabase. (In, Required)
The geodatabase hosting the relative replica. The geodatabase may be local or remote. (In, Required)

The direction in which you want changes to be sent: from geodatabase 1 to geodatabase 2, from geodatabase 2 to geodatabase 1, or to send changes in both directions. For check-out/check-in replicas or one-way replicas there is only one appropriate direction. If the replica is two-way then any of the three choices are available. (In, Required)
Specifies how conflicts are resolved when they are encountered. (In, Required)

param.name: conflict_definition
param.summary: Specifies how you would like to define conflicts: (In, Required)

param.name: reconcile
param.summary: Indicates whether to automatically reconcile once data changes are sent to the parent replica if there are no conflicts present. This option is only available for check-out/check-in replicas. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges.geodatabase_1
member.summary: The geodatabase hosting the replica to synchronize. The geodatabase may be local or remote. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges.in_replica
member.summary: A valid replica with a parent contained within one input geodatabase and a child in the other input geodatabase. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges.geodatabase_2
member.summary: The geodatabase hosting the relative replica. The geodatabase may be local or remote. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SynchronizeChanges.in_direction
member.summary: The direction in which you want changes to be sent: from geodatabase 1 to geodatabase 2, from geodatabase 2 to geodatabase 1, or to send changes in both directions. For check-out/check-in replicas or one-way replicas there is only one appropriate direction. If the replica is two-way then any of the three choices are available. (In, Required)

member.summary: Specifies how conflicts are resolved when they are encountered. (In, Required)

member.summary: Specifies how you would like to define conflicts: (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster
member.summary: Saves a copy of a raster dataset or converts a mosaic dataset into a single raster dataset.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The raster dataset or mosaic dataset you want to copy. (In, Required)
The name and format for the raster dataset you are creating. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.in_raster
member.summary: The raster dataset or mosaic dataset you want to copy. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.out_rasterdataset
member.summary: The name and format for the raster dataset you are creating. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.config_keyword
member.summary: Specifies the storage parameters (configuration) for a geodatabase. Configuration keywords are set up by your database administrator. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.background_value
member.summary: Remove the unwanted values created around the raster data. The value specified will be distinguished from other valuable data in the raster dataset. For example, a value of zero along the raster dataset's borders will be distinguished from zero values within the raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.nodata_value
member.summary: All the pixels with the specified value will be set to NoData in the output raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.onebit_to_eightbit
member.summary: Choose whether the input 1-bit raster dataset will be converted to an 8-bit raster dataset. In this conversion, the value 1 in the input raster dataset will be changed to 255 in the output raster dataset. This is useful when importing a 1-bit raster dataset to a geodatabase. One-bit raster datasets have 8-bit pyramid layers when stored in a file system, but in a geodatabase, 1-bit raster datasets can only have 1-bit pyramid layers, which makes the display unpleasant. By converting the data to 8 bit in a geodatabase, the pyramid layers are built as 8 bit instead of 1 bit, resulting in a proper raster dataset in the display. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.colormap_to_RGB
member.summary: If the input raster dataset has a color map, the output raster dataset can be converted to a three-band output raster dataset. This is useful when mosaicking rasters with different color maps. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.pixel_type
member.summary: Set the bit depth, or radiometric resolution, of the raster or mosaic dataset. If not defined, it will be taken from the first raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.scale_pixel_value
member.summary: When the output is a different pixel type than the input (such as 16 bit to 8 bit), you can choose to have the values scaled to fit into the new range; otherwise, the values that do not fit into the new pixel range will be discarded. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.RGB_to_Colormap
member.summary: Convert an 8-bit, 3-band (RGB) raster dataset to a single-band raster dataset with a color map. This operation suppresses noise that is often found in scanned images and is ideal for screen captures, scanned maps, or scanned documents. This is not recommended for satellite or aerial imagery or thematic raster data. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.format
member.summary: The output raster format. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CopyRaster.transform
member.summary: Apply the transformation associated with the raster to the output. The input raster can have a transformation associated with it, that is, not actually saved within the input, such as a world file or as a geometric function. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool's toolbox.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic
member.summary: Merges multiple existing raster datasets into an existing raster dataset.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The raster datasets you want to merge together. (In, Required)

param.name: target
param.summary: The raster to add the input rasters. This raster dataset must already exist. By default, the target raster is considered the first raster in the list of input raster datasets. You can create an empty raster using the Create Raster Dataset tool. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.inputs
member.summary: The raster datasets you want to merge together. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.target
member.summary: The raster to add the input rasters. This raster dataset must already exist. By default, the target raster is considered the first raster in the list of input raster datasets. You can create an empty raster using the Create Raster Dataset tool. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.mosaic_type
member.summary: The method used to mosaic overlapping areas. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.colormap
member.summary: The method used to choose which color map from the input rasters will be applied to the mosaic output. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.background_value
member.summary: Use this option to remove the unwanted values created around the raster data. The value specified will be distinguished from other valuable data in the raster dataset. For example, a value of zero along the raster dataset's borders will be distinguished from zero values in the raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.nodata_value
member.summary: All the pixels with the specified value will be set to NoData in the output raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.onebit_to_eightbit
member.summary: Choose whether the input 1-bit raster dataset will be converted to an 8-bit raster dataset. In this conversion, the value 1 in the input raster dataset will be changed to 255 in the output raster dataset. This is useful when importing a 1-bit raster dataset to a geodatabase. One-bit raster datasets have 8-bit pyramid layers when stored in a file system, but in a geodatabase, 1-bit raster datasets can only have 1-bit pyramid layers, which makes the display unpleasant. By converting the data to 8 bit in a geodatabase, the pyramid layers are built as 8 bit instead of 1 bit, resulting in a proper raster dataset in the display. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.mosaicking_tolerance
member.summary: When mosaicking takes place, the target and the source pixels do not always line up exactly. When there is a misalignment of pixels, a decision needs to be made whether resampling takes place or whether the data should be shifted. The mosaicking tolerance controls whether resampling of the pixels take place or if the pixels should be shifted. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.output
member.summary: Output Raster (out, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Mosaic.MatchingMethod
member.summary: Choose the color matching method to apply to the rasters. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateRasterCatalog.spatial_grid_1
member.summary: The spatial_grid_1, spatial_grid_2, and spatial_grid_3 parameters are used to compute a spatial index and only apply to file geodatabases and enterprise geodatabases. If you are unfamiliar with setting grid sizes, leave these options as 0,0,0 and ArcGIS will compute optimal sizes for you. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateRasterCatalog.spatial_grid_2
member.summary: Cell size of the second spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want one grid. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Spatial Grid 1. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.CreateRasterCatalog.spatial_grid_3
member.summary:
Cell size of the third spatial grid. Leave the size at 0 if you only want two grids. Otherwise, set the size to at least three times larger than Spatial Grid 2.
(In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.Dice
member.summary: Subdivides a feature into smaller features based on a specified vertex limit. This tool is intended as a way to subdivide extremely large features that cause issues with drawing, analysis, editing, and/or performance but are difficult to split up with standard editing and geoprocessing tools. This tool should not be used in any cases other than those where tools are failing to complete successfully due to the size of features.

member.param: The input feature class or feature layer. The geometry type must be multipoint, line, or polygon. (In, Required)

member.summary: The destination for the new raster datasets. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.out_base_name
member.summary: The prefix for each of the raster datasets you will create. A number will be appended to each prefix, starting with 0. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.split_method
member.summary: Determines how to split the raster dataset. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.format
member.summary: The format for the output raster datasets. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.resampling_type
member.summary: Choose an appropriate technique based on the type of data you have. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.num_rasters
member.summary: The number of columns (x) and rows (y) to split the raster dataset into. This is a point whose X and Y coordinates define number of rows and columns. The X coordinate is the number of columns and the Y coordinate is the number of rows. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.tile_size
member.summary: The x and y dimensions of the output tiles. The default unit of measurement is in pixels. You can change this with the units parameter. This is a point whose X and Y coordinates define the dimensions of output tiles. The X coordinate is the horizontal dimension of the output and the Y coordinate is the vertical dimension of the output. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.overlap
member.summary: The tiles do not have to line up perfectly; set the amount of overlap between tiles with this parameter. The default unit of measurement is in pixels. You can change this with the units parameter. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.units
member.summary: Set the units of measurement for the tile_size and the overlap parameters. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.cell_size
member.summary: The spatial resolution of the output raster. If left blank, the output cell size will match the input raster. When you change the cell size values, the tile size is reset to the image size and the tile count is reset to 1. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.origin
member.summary: Change the coordinates for the lower left origin point, where the tiling scheme will begin. If left blank, the lower left origin would be the same as the input raster. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.split_polygon_feature_class
member.summary: A feature class that will be used to split the raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.clip_type
member.summary: Limits the extent of your raster dataset before you split it. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.template_extent
member.summary: An extent or a dataset used to define the clipping boundary. The dataset can be a raster or feature class. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.SplitRaster.nodata_value
member.summary: All the pixels with the specified value will be set to NoData in the output raster dataset. (In, Optional)

member.summary: Output Folder (out, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase
member.summary: Registers feature classes, tables, views, and raster layers that were created in the database using ArcGIS clients with the geodatabase. Once registered, information about the itemsâ€”such as table and column names, spatial extent, and geometry typeâ€”is stored in the geodatabase's system tables, allowing these registered items to participate in geodatabase functionality.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

param.name: in_dataset
param.summary: The feature class, table, view, or raster created using third-party tools or SQL that you want to register with the geodatabase. The dataset must exist in the same database as the geodatabase. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_dataset
member.summary: The feature class, table, view, or raster created using third-party tools or SQL that you want to register with the geodatabase. The dataset must exist in the same database as the geodatabase. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.reg_dataset
member.summary: Registered Dataset (out, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_object_id_field
member.summary: The field that will be used as the ObjectID field. This input is required when registering a view, and you must supply an existing integer field. This parameter is optional when registering other dataset types; if using an existing field it must be an integer data type. If an existing field is not supplied, a new ObjectID field will be created and populated. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_shape_field
member.summary: If the input dataset contains a shape column, include this during the registration process. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_geometry_type
member.summary: If the in_shape_field is present, you must specify a geometry type. If the dataset being registered contains existing features, the geometry type specified must match the entity type of these features. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_spatial_reference
member.summary: If the in_shape_field is present and the table is empty, specify the coordinate system to be used for features. If the dataset being registered contains existing features, the coordinate system specified must match the coordinate system of the existing features. Valid values are a Spatial Reference object, a file with a .prj extension, or a string representation of a coordinate system. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.RegisterWithGeodatabase.in_extent
member.summary: If the in_shape_field is present, specify the allowable coordinate range for x,y coordinates in the following order: "XMin YMin XMax YMax". If the dataset being registered contains existing features, the extent of the existing features will be used. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.ConsolidateMap.preserve_sqlite
member.summary: Instead of converting to a file geodatabase format, input SQLite data can be preserved as SQLite output. This parameter overrides the convert_data parameter when the input data is SQLite. If the input data is a SQLite network dataset, the output will always be SQLite. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BearingDistanceToLine
member.summary: Creates a new feature class containing geodetic line features constructed based on the values in an x-coordinate field, y-coordinate field, bearing field, and distance field of a table.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BearingDistanceToLine.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

param.name: in_table
param.summary: The input table that can be a text file, CSV file, Excel file, dBASE table, or geodatabase table. (In, Required)

param.name: out_featureclass
param.summary: The output feature class containing densified geodetic lines. (Out, Required)

member.param: A numerical field in the input table containing the x coordinates (or longitudes) of the starting points of lines to be positioned in the output coordinate system specified by the spatial_reference parameter. (In, Required)

A numerical field in the input table containing the y coordinates (or latitudes) of the starting points of lines to be positioned in the output coordinate system specified by the spatial_reference parameter. (In, Required)

param.name: distance_field
param.summary: A numerical field in the input table containing the distances from the starting points for creating the output lines. (In, Required)

param.name: distance_units
param.summary: The units for the values in the distance_field. (In, Required)

param.name: bearing_field
param.summary: A numerical field in the input table containing bearing angle values for the output line rotation. The angles are measured clockwise from North. (In, Required)

param.name: bearing_units
param.summary: The units of the values in the bearing_field. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BearingDistanceToLine.in_table
member.summary: The input table that can be a text file, CSV file, Excel file, dBASE table, or geodatabase table. (In, Required)

member.summary: The output feature class containing densified geodetic lines. (Out, Required)

member.summary: The units of the values in the bearing_field. (In, Required)

member.summary: The type of geodetic line to construct. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BearingDistanceToLine.id_field
member.summary: A field in the input table; this field and the values are included in the output and can be used to join the output features with the records in the input table. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BearingDistanceToLine.spatial_reference
member.summary: The spatial reference of the output feature class. You can specify the spatial reference in several ways: By entering the path to a .prj file, such as C:/workspace/watershed.prj. By referencing a feature class or feature dataset whose spatial reference you want to apply, such as C:/workspace/myproject.gdb/landuse/grassland. By defining a spatial reference object prior to using this tool, such as sr = arcpy.SpatialReference("C:/data/Africa/Carthage.prj"), which you then use as the spatial reference parameter. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics
member.summary: Traverses a folder structure, building pyramids and calculating statistics for all the raster datasets it contains. It can also build pyramids and calculate statistics for all the items in a mosaic dataset.

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The workspace that contains all the raster datasets to be processed, a mosaic dataset, or a raster catalog. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.in_workspace
member.summary: The workspace that contains all the raster datasets to be processed, a mosaic dataset, or a raster catalog. (In, Required)

member.summary: Specify whether to include subdirectories. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.build_pyramids
member.summary: Specify whether to build pyramids. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.calculate_statistics
member.summary: Specify whether to calculate statistics. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.BUILD_ON_SOURCE
member.summary: Specify whether to build pyramids and calculate statistics on the source raster datasets, or calculate statistics on the raster items in a mosaic dataset. This option only applies to mosaic datasets. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The name of the field within a mosaic dataset's attribute table used to identify items that should be considered one item when performing some calculations and operations. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.estimate_statistics
member.summary: Specify whether to calculate statistics for the mosaic dataset (not the rasters within it). The statistics are derived from the existing statistics that have been calculated for each raster in the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.x_skip_factor
member.summary: The number of horizontal pixels between samples. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.y_skip_factor
member.summary: The number of vertical pixels between samples. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.ignore_values
member.summary: The pixel values that are not to be included in the statistics calculation. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.pyramid_level
member.summary: Choose the number of reduced-resolution dataset layers that will be built. The default value is -1, which will build full pyramids. A value of 0 will result in no pyramid levels. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.SKIP_FIRST
member.summary: Choose whether to skip the first pyramid level. Skipping the first level will take up slightly less disk space, but it will slow down performance at these scales. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.resample_technique
member.summary: The resampling technique used to build your pyramids. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.compression_type
member.summary: The compression type to use when building the raster pyramids. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildPyramidsandStatistics.compression_quality
member.summary: The compression quality to use when pyramids are built with the JPEG compression method. The value must be between 0 and 100. The values closer to 100 will produce a higher-quality image, but the compression ratio will be lower. (In, Optional)

member.summary: Adds raster datasets to a mosaic dataset from many sources, including a file, folder, table, or web service.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The path and name of the mosaic dataset to which the raster data will be added. (In, Required)
The raster type is specific to imagery products. It identifies metadata, such as georeferencing, acquisition date, and sensor type, along with a raster format. (In, Required)
Specifies the path and name of the file, folder, raster dataset, mosaic dataset, table, or service. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.in_mosaic_dataset
member.summary: The path and name of the mosaic dataset to which the raster data will be added. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.raster_type
member.summary: The raster type is specific to imagery products. It identifies metadata, such as georeferencing, acquisition date, and sensor type, along with a raster format. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.input_path
member.summary: Specifies the path and name of the file, folder, raster dataset, mosaic dataset, table, or service. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.update_cellsize_ranges
member.summary: Specifies whether the cell size ranges of each raster in the mosaic dataset will be calculated. These values are written to the attribute table in the minPS and maxPS fields. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.update_boundary
member.summary: Specifies whether the boundary polygon of a mosaic dataset will be generated or updated. By default, the boundary merges all the footprint polygons to create a single boundary representing the extent of the valid pixels. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.update_overviews
member.summary: Specifies whether overviews for a mosaic dataset will be defined and generated. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.maximum_pyramid_levels
member.summary: The maximum number of pyramid levels that will be used in the mosaic dataset. For example, a value of 2 will use only the first two pyramid levels from the source raster. Leaving this parameter blank or typing a value of -1 will build pyramids for all levels. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.maximum_cell_size
member.summary: The maximum pyramid cell size that will be used in the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.minimum_dimension
member.summary: The minimum dimensions of a raster pyramid that will be used in the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.spatial_reference
member.summary: The spatial reference system of the input data. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.filter
member.summary: A filter for the data being added to the mosaic dataset. You can use SQL expressions to create the data filter. The wildcards for the filter work on the full path to the input data. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.sub_folder
member.summary: Specifies whether subfolders will be recursively explored. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.duplicate_items_action
member.summary: Specifies how duplicate rasters will be handled. A check will be performed to see if each raster has already been added, using the original path and file name. Choose the action to be performed when a duplicate path and file name are found. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.build_pyramids
member.summary: Builds pyramids for each source raster. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.calculate_statistics
member.summary: Specifies whether statistics will be calculated for each source raster. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.build_thumbnails
member.summary: Specifies whether thumbnails will be built for each source raster. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.operation_description
member.summary: The description used to represent the operation of adding raster data. It will be added to the raster type table, which can be used as part of a search or as a reference at another time. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.force_spatial_reference
member.summary: Specifies the coordinate system. Use the coordinate system specified in the spatial_reference parameter for all the rasters when loading data into the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.estimate_statistics
member.summary: Specifies whether statistics are estimated on the mosaic dataset for faster rendering and processing at the mosaic dataset level. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.AddRastersToMosaicDataset.aux_inputs
member.summary: The raster type settings that will be defined on the Raster Type Properties page. The settings in this parameter will override the settings defined on the Raster Type Properties page. (In, Optional)

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

member.summary: Select the mosaic dataset where you want to recompute the boundary. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildBoundary.where_clause
member.summary: An SQL query to compute a boundary for select raster datasets. Use this option in conjunction with setting the append_to_existing parameter to APPEND to save time when adding new raster datasets. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildBoundary.append_to_existing
member.summary: Set this to APPEND when adding new raster datasets to an existing mosaic dataset. Instead of calculating the entire boundary, APPEND will merge the boundary of the new raster datasets with the existing boundary. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildBoundary.simplification_method
member.summary: The simplification method reduces the number of vertices, since a dense boundary can affect performance. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints
member.summary: Computes the extent of every raster in a mosaic dataset. This tool is used when you have added or removed raster datasets from a mosaic dataset and want to recompute the footprints.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The mosaic dataset that contains the raster datasets whose footprints you want to compute. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.in_mosaic_dataset
member.summary: The mosaic dataset that contains the raster datasets whose footprints you want to compute. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.where_clause
member.summary: An SQL expression to select specific raster datasets within the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.reset_footprint
member.summary: Refine the footprints using one of the following methods: (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.min_data_value
member.summary: Exclude pixels with a value less than this number. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.max_data_value
member.summary: Exclude pixels with a value greater than this number. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.approx_num_vertices
member.summary: Choose between 4 and 10,000. More vertices will improve accuracy but can extend processing time. A value of -1 will calculate all vertices. More vertices will increase accuracy but also the processing time. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.shrink_distance
member.summary: Clip the footprint by this distance. This can eliminate artifacts from using lossy compression, which causes the edges of the image to overlap into NoData areas. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.maintain_edges
member.summary: Use this parameter when using raster datasets that have been tiled and are adjacent (line up along the seams with little to no overlap). (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.skip_derived_images
member.summary: Adjust the footprints of overviews. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.update_boundary
member.summary: Update the boundary of the mosaic dataset if you have added or removed imagery that changes the extent. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.request_size
member.summary: Set the resampled extent (in columns and rows) for the raster when building footprints. Greater image resolution provides more detail in the raster dataset but increases the processing time. A value of -1 will compute the footprint at the original resolution. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.min_region_size
member.summary: Avoid small holes in your imagery when using pixel values to create a mask. For example, your imagery may have a range of values from 0 to 255, and to mask clouds, you've excluded values from 245 to 255, which may cause other, noncloud pixels to be masked as well. If those areas are smaller than the number of pixels specified here, they will not be masked out. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.simplification_method
member.summary: Reduce the number of vertices in the footprint to improve performance. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.edge_tolerance
member.summary: Snap the footprint to the sheet edge if it is within this tolerance. Units are the same as those in the mosaic dataset coordinate system. This is used when maintain_edges is set to MAINTAIN_EDGES. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.max_sliver_size
member.summary: Identify all polygons that are smaller than the square of this value. The value is specified in pixels and is based on the request_size, not the spatial resolution of the source raster. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.min_thinness_ratio
member.summary: Define the thinness of slivers on a scale from 0 to 1.0, where 1.0 represents a circle and 0.0 represents a polygon that approaches a straight line. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildFootprints.out_mosaic_dataset
member.summary: Mosaic Dataset (out, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool.

member.summary: The alias for this tool's toolbox.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines
member.summary: Generate or update seamlines for your mosaic dataset. Seamlines are used to sort overlapping imagery and produce a smoother-looking mosaic.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: Select the mosaic dataset on which to build seamlines. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.in_mosaic_dataset
member.summary: Select the mosaic dataset on which to build seamlines. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.cell_size
member.summary: Generate seamlines for raster datasets that fall within the following range of spatial resolutions. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.sort_method
member.summary: Set a rule to determine which raster will be used to generate seamlines when images overlap. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.sort_order
member.summary: Choose whether to sort the rasters in ascending order or descending order. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.order_by_attribute
member.summary: Order the raster datasets based on this field when the sort method is BY_ATTRIBUTE. The default attribute is ObjectID. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.order_by_base_value
member.summary: Sort the rasters by their difference between this value and their value in the order_by_attribute parameter. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.view_point
member.summary: Set the coordinate location to use when sort_method is CLOSEST_TO_VIEWPOINT. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.computation_method
member.summary: Choose how to build seamlines. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.blend_width
member.summary: Blending (feathering) occurs along a seamline between pixels where there are overlapping rasters. The blend width defines how many pixels will be blended. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.blend_type
member.summary: Determine how to blend one image into another, over the seamlines. Options are to blend inside the seamlines, outside the seamlines, or both inside and outside. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.request_size
member.summary: Specify the number of columns and rows for resampling. The maximum value is 5,000. Increase or decrease this value based on the complexity of your raster data. Greater image resolution provides more detail in the raster dataset but also increases the processing time. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.request_size_type
member.summary: Set the units for the Request Size. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.blend_width_units
member.summary: Specify the unit of measurement for blend width. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.area_of_interest
member.summary: Build seamlines on all the rasters that intersect this polygon. To select an area of interest, use an input feature class. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.where_clause
member.summary: SQL expression to build seamlines on specific raster datasets within the mosaic dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.update_existing
member.summary: Update seamlines that are affected by the addition or deletion of the mosaic dataset items. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.out_mosaic_dataset
member.summary: Mosaic Dataset (out, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.min_region_size
member.summary: Specify the minimum region size, in pixel units. Any polygons smaller than this specified threshold will be removed in the seamline result. The default is 100 pixels. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.min_thinness_ratio
member.summary: Define how thin a polygon can be, before it is considered a sliver. This is based on a scale from 0 to 1.0, where a value of 0.0 represents a polygon that is almost a straight line, and a value of 1.0 represents a polygon that is a circle. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.BuildSeamlines.max_sliver_size
member.summary: Specify the maximum size a polygon can be to still be considered a sliver. This parameter is specified in pixels and is based on the request_size, not the spatial resolution of the source raster. Any polygon that is less than the square of this value is considered a sliver. Any regions that are less than (max_sliver_size)2 are considered slivers. (In, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool.

member.summary: The alias for this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The parameters used by this tool. For internal use only.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.ComputeDirtyArea
member.summary: Identifies areas within a mosaic dataset that have changed since a specified point in time. This is used commonly when a mosaic dataset is updated or synchronized, or when derived products, such as cache, need to be updated. This tool will enable you to limit such processes to only the areas that have changed.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.DataManagementTools.ComputeDirtyArea.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The mosaic dataset that you want to analyze for changes. (In, Required)
